Harold Ollivier

Limitations of variational quantum algorithms: a quantum optimal transport approach

Apr 17, 2023

Definitions

Definition 1. The Lipschitz constant for H a self-adjoint operator is defined by: ∥H∥L = 2maxv ∈ VminH\v∥H − H\v ⊗ 𝕀v∥∞

Definition 2. The sandwiched Renyi divergence of order α ∈ (1,+∞) is defined for two quantum states ρ, σ with supp ρ ⊂ supp σ as $$D_{\alpha} (\rho \| \sigma) = \frac{1}{\alpha-1} \log \mathrm{tr} \left[\left(\sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right )^\alpha\right]$$

Definition 3. A state σ on V qudits satisfies a Gaussian concentration inequality of parameter c if there is a constant K such that for any a and any observable O: $$\Pr_{\sigma} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq K \exp \left( - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2}\right)$$

Above $|A| = \sqrt {A^\dagger A}$, and Prσ(|O−⟨O⟩σ𝕀>a|V|) means that for E the positive part of |O−⟨O⟩σ𝕀| − a|V|𝕀, we have $\mathrm{tr}(E\sigma)$ bounded by the right hand side of the equation. Note that in the cases where σ and O commute ∥σ−1/2Oσ1/2∥L2 reduces to ∥O∥L2.

Transferring inequalities

Theorem 1. Let ρ, σ be two quantum states on ℋV. Then for any POVM element 0 ≤ E ≤ 𝕀 and α > 1, $$\mathrm{tr}[E\rho] \leq \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma) + \log(\mathrm{tr}[E\sigma]))\right)$$

Proof. Using the circularity of the trace we have: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr}[E\rho] & = \mathrm{tr}[\sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \times \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}] \\ & \leq \left\{\mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right)^\beta \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\beta}} \times \left\{\mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \right)^\alpha \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\end{aligned}$$ where the last line is obtained by applying Hölder inequality, which holds for $\frac{1}{\alpha} + \frac{1}{\beta} = 1$.

Using the Araki-Lieb-Thirring inequality followed by E ≤ 𝕀 we obtain: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right)^\beta & \leq \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E^\beta \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right) \\ & \leq \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right).\end{aligned}$$ As $\beta = \frac{\alpha}{\alpha -1}$ we have $$\mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right)=\mathrm{tr}(E\sigma).$$

Additionally, note that $$\left \{ \mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \right)^\alpha \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\alpha}} = \exp (\frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma)).$$

Combining the two gives: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr}[E\rho] & \leq (tr[E\sigma]) \times \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma))\right) \\ & \leq \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma)) \log (\mathrm{tr}[E\sigma])\right).\end{aligned}$$ ◻

Remark that the theorem bounds the probability of observing E on ρ based on the product of the probability of observing E on σ times a quantity that depends on Dα(ρ∥σ), which can be seen as a measure of the distance between the two states ρ and σ. This will become interesting whenever Dα(ρ∥σ) becomes small.

Corollary 1. If σ satisfies a Gaussian concentration inequality $$\Pr_{\sigma} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq K \exp \left( - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2}\right)$$ for some constant c, K > 0, then for any α > 1: $$\Pr_{\rho} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq \exp \left(\frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha}\left(D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma) - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2} + \log(K)\right)\right)$$

Corollary 2. For an input state ρ, a noisy circuit evolution 𝒩(ρ) and a state σ satisfying a Gaussian concentration inequality, whenever there is a value of α and a such that $$\frac{D_{\alpha}(\mathcal N(\rho) \| \sigma)}{|V|} < \frac{c a^2}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2} - \frac{\log(K)}{|V|},$$ then the probability of observing an outcome of O outside the interval ⟨O⟩σ ± a|V| decreases exponentially with |V|.

Bounding Dα(𝒩(ρ)∥σ)

Such bounds can be obtained for noisy circuits where each layer i is followed by a noisy channel 𝒩 with a fixed point σ satisfying a strong data processing inequality: Dα(𝒩(ρ)∥σ) ≤ (1−q)Dα(ρ∥σ), ∀ρ.

In such cases we obtain

Lemma 1. Let 𝒩 be a quantum channel with a unique fixed point σ and satisfying a strong data processing inequality for some α > 1, then for any other channels {Φi}i ≤ l we have: Dα(𝒫(ρ)∥σ) ≤ (1−q)lDα(ρ∥σ) + ∑i ≤ l(1−q)l − iD∞(Φi(σ)∥σ) where $D_\infty(\rho \| \sigma) = \log \| \sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}} \rho \sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\|_\infty$, and 𝒫 = ∏i ≤ lΦi ∘ 𝒩.

Proof. We proceed by induction on l. For l = 1, we use the data processed triangle inequality: Dα(Φ1∘𝒩(ρ)∥σ) ≤ Dα(𝒩(ρ)∥σ) + D∞(Φ1(σ)∥σ) ≤ (1−q)Dα(ρ∥σ) + D∞(Φ1(σ)∥σ). The induction is performed in the same way, assuming the property holds for some l and then applying the data processed triangle inequality. ◻

Note that for unital channels 𝒩(σ) = σ as the fixed point of the channel is 𝕀. This implies that Dα(𝒫(ρ)∥σ) will always converge to 0.

Additional notes

Renyi entropies

In the above definition of Renyi divergence, note that when α → 1 we recover the usual relative entropy: $$D_1 (\rho \| \sigma) = \mathrm{tr}(\rho (\log \rho - \log \sigma))$$

This is not a surprise as these sandwiched Renyi divergences have been introduced as a generalization of the usual relative entropy. Renyi entropies $\frac{1}{1-\alpha} \log \frac{\mathrm{tr} \rho^\alpha}{\mathrm{tr} \rho}$ are also generalizations of von Neumann entropy in that they preserve important properties:

  • Continuity

  • Unitary invariance

  • Normalization

  • Additivity.

Relative entropy and Pinsker inequality

The Pinsker inequality relates the relative entropy to the trace distance. As such it allows to bound the trace distance using information theoretic arguments: $$D_1(\rho\|\sigma) \geq \frac{1}{2\log 2} \| \rho -\sigma \|_{\mathrm{tr}}^2$$

Hölder inequality

For A, B operators on ℋ $$\|AB\|_1 \leq \|A\|_p \|B\|_q, \quad \frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$$ which translates for matrices into $$\mathrm{tr}(|AB|) \leq [\mathrm{tr}(|A|^{p})]^{1/p} \times [\mathrm{tr}(|B|^{q})]^{1/q}, \quad \frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1.$$

Araki-Lieb-Thirring inequality

For A, B ≥ 0, q ≥ 0 and 0 ≤ r ≤ 1 then $$\mathrm{tr}[(A^rB^rA^r)^q] \leq\mathrm{tr}[(ABA)^{rq}].$$ When r ≥ 1 the inequality is reversed.
